marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Collection contains a deed between Edward Jackson (Middlesex Co.) and John Slade (Suffolk Co.) for land in Suffolk Co., Mass., 1779; 1850 correspondence with Samuel Foster Haven concerning THE RECORDS OF THE COMPANY OF THE MASSACHUSETTS BAY; and 1880s letters to C.C. Jones concerning Jones's writings.
Records of the company of the Massachusetts Bay.
George Wymberley Jones De Renne papers,

Letters to De Renne concern the Buchanan administration; the president's nephew, Cole Baker; politics and politicians of the era; railroad building in Georgia and South Carolina; the coming of the Civil War; news and views of Reconstruction (during which the De Renne family lived abroad in France); the Black Republican Party; and suffrage for African Americans. Correspondents include F. Dainese, Thomas F. Drayton, James H. Hammond, H.I. McIntyre, James P. Screven, and John Screven. There are also some papers of the Central Bank of Georgia. Two items concern Dr. George Jones, father of G.W. Jones (later known as G.W. Jones De Renne), consisting of an 1782 affidavit concerning his imprisonment by the British and a receipt for the sale of a slave.

Collection consists of assorted correspondence relating to national and state politics, nullification, and internal improvements, especially canals and railroads in the Boston area and in Pennsylvania. Includes discussion of a treaty with the Tuscarora Indians in N.C.; the 1832 presidential election; and the nullification crisis. Correspondents include Henry Dearborn (H.A.S. Dearborn's father), Joseph Gardner Swift, and Gerard Ralston.
Portions of this collection were originally part of the Don Preston Peters collection. Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1936-1960s.

Letters to and from William Dehon, an Episcopal clergyman of Pineville, S.C., and his family and friends. Topics mentioned in letters from family members in Charleston, S.C. include vaccination for smallpox and vericella; and the religious life and instruction of slaves. Letters from family members provide accounts of travels in France, England, Ireland, and New York. A few letters contain information regarding women's fashions and hairstyles.
Collection contains business papers, including references to Samuel Garland (?) and Christopher T. Estes.
Cataloged from Guide. Originally part of the Don Preston Peters Collection.
Commission as captain in the 33rd Kentucky Militia Regiment for Augustus Frederick, signed by Joseph Desha, governor of Kentucky.
Resident of China Grove, North Carolina.
Family correspondence concerning social life and customs, and farming in Iredell County, N.C., and Grant County, Kan.
Originally part of the Marmaduke Floyd Collection. Cataloged from card file, 1956.
Collection largely contains documents relating to the ownership of land in South Carolina. Included are a few letters, some by DeLettre, discussing family affairs.
Collection contains letters from W.H. Dennis of Richmond, Va., to his brother John, mentioning education, slavery and slave prices, tobacco, cotton prices and crops, and politics.
Clergyman, writer, professor, and college president of Greensboro Female College (1850-1854). Established the Church of the Strangers in New York City, 1868.

Collection contains letters about Cornelius Vanderbilt's philanthropy, Deems's publications, and the American Institute of Christian Philosophy; and a printed flier advertising Deems's THE ANNALS OF SOUTHERN METHODISM for 1855 and 1856.
New York, N.Y. and Savannah, Ga. resident.

Collection contains letters from Thomas L. Snead and George N. Lester, former Confederate congressman, in response to Dawson's requests for their autographs; and a letter, 1856, by Dawson, possibly to T.R.R. Cobb, concerning politics, speeches by R.A. Toombs and A.H. Stephens, and Millard Fillmore's chances for the presidency.

Collection contains letters from Confederate soldiers addressed to Mary Davison, mostly from the 28th Regiment of N.C. Infantry, describing army life, camp, and illnesses; a battle at Cape Hatteras, 1861; the shooting of an African-American who was allegedly trying to burn a bridge; descriptions of Fort Fisher and Wilmington.
Cataloged from card file; description dating from 1934, 1957.
Nurseryman or florist of Nyack (Rockland Co.), N.Y.

Collection contains letters, checks, bills, receipts, and a telegram to De Pew, from Peter De Pew, Grace A. Gruman, and others. Topics include an order for trees; letters about flowers and shrubs; preparations for the 1929 presidential inauguration.
Cataloged from Guide; description from card file, 1949.
Originally part of the Marmaduke Floyd Collection. Cataloged from card file; originally cataloged in 1944 and 1957.

Collection contains philosophical musings of J.J. Flournoy, written in the form of letters and addressed to B. A. Denmark. Collection also contains a letter from Henry B. Thompkins introducing Denmark to Josephus Camp.
Alabama legislator and Confederate Army captain; from Selma (Dallas Co.), Ala.
Civil War correspondence relative to the early campaigns in Virginia.
Plan of Battle of Manasas or Bull Run Sunday July 21st 1861 from sketches on the spot by F. C. DeLamar,
F. C. Delamar map of Manassas battlefield,
Manuscript map of the battlefield at Manassas (Bull Run), Va. It is unclear whether DeLamar made the map as well as the sketches upon which it was based.
Prominent Moravian and principal of the Salem Female Academy, 1853-1866, from Salem (Forsyth Co.), N.C.
Printed forms and letters explaining the increase in the cost of tuition and board at the Salem Female Academy, from June to December, 1862.

Letters to Julia Deane from Confederate soldiers commenting on their activities in the field, the defense of Richmond in 1864, and the prospects of peace. Most of the letters are from William A. Peacock.
Confederate soldier, member of the 26th North Carolina Infantry Regiment, from Caledonia (Moore Co.), N.C.
Letters to relatives describing the battle of Gettysburg; prison life at Point Lookout, Md.; and mentioning the health and fortunes of various other soldiers.
Union soldier writing from Chattanooga, Tenn.
Description from card file; originally described 1942.
Letters describing a Union camp in Somerville, W. Va., and the battle of Chickamauga.

Topics of these miscellaneous letters include the use of substitutes in the draft in New York; conditions around Shell Mound, Tenn., after occupation by Union troops; the occupation of Charleston, S.C., by African American troops; and a school for freedmen run by Union troops on Sullivan's Island. Writers of these letters are Julian F. DeWitt and other members of the DeWitt family, and James G. Foster.
Collection contains papers relating to the title to lands of Black Point plantation lands and their sale.
Originally part of the Marmaduke Floyd Collection.
Business papers of a corn and wheat dealer and miller of Kinsley Mills (Prince William Co.), Va.
A. V. Burns letter to James William Denver,

Born in Va., Denver moved with his parents to Ohio and later practiced law in Ohio and Missouri. During the Mexican War, he served as captain in the 12th U.S. Volunteer Infantry. In 1850, he moved to California and became a state senator, secretary of state for Cal. and then a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. He was later appointed Commissioner of Indian Affairs and then governor of the Territory of Kansas. During the first part of the Civil War, he commanded a brigade in the Army of Tennessee. In 1863 he returned to practicing law, remaining active in politics both in Ohio and Washington, D.C.

Collection consists of one letter to Denver from A.V. Burns, dated Jan. 17, 1874, from Gilroy, California. Burns thanks Denver for interest he takes in the survivors of the Mexican War and refers to early political campaigns in California, the hardships of the Mexican War, and frontier conditions in California.
Cataloged from accession record and card catalog.
Two letters by De Leon discussing writing and publishing.
